review.title: DeepNAT: Deep Convolutional Neural Network for Segmenting Neuroanatomy
review.abstract: We introduce DeepNAT, a 3D Deep convolutional neural network for the automatic segmentation of NeuroAnaTomy in T1-weighted magnetic resonance images. DeepNAT is an end-to-end learning-based approach to brain segmentation that jointly learns an abstract feature representation and a multi-class classification. We propose a 3D patch-based approach, where we do not only predict the center voxel of the patch but also neighbors, which is formulated as multi-task learning. To address a class imbalance problem, we arrange two networks hierarchically, where the first one separates foreground from background, and the second one identifies 25 brain structures on the foreground. Since patches lack spatial context, we augment them with coordinates. To this end, we introduce a novel intrinsic parameterization of the brain volume, formed by eigenfunctions of the Laplace-Beltrami operator. As network architecture, we use three convolutional layers with pooling, batch normalization, and non-linearities, followed by fully connected layers with dropout. The final segmentation is inferred from the probabilistic output of the network with a 3D fully connected conditional random field, which ensures label agreement between close voxels. The roughly 2.7 million parameters in the network are learned with stochastic gradient descent. Our results show that DeepNAT compares favorably to state-of-the-art methods. Finally, the purely learning-based method may have a high potential for the adaptation to young, old, or diseased brains by fine-tuning the pre-trained network with a small training sample on the target application, where the availability of larger datasets with manual annotations may boost the overall segmentation accuracy in the future.

sections.text: We introduce DeepNAT, a 3D Deep Convolutional Neural Network for the automatic segmentation of NeuroAnaTomy into T1-weighted magnetic resonance images. DeepNAT is an end-to-end learning-based approach to brain segmentation that collectively learns an abstract representation of features and a multi-class classification. We propose a 3D patch-based approach in which we predict not only the central voxel of the patch, but also its neighbors, which are formulated as multi-task learning. To address a class imbalance problem, we arrange two networks hierarchically, the first separating the foreground from the background, and the second identifying 25 brain structures in the foreground. As patches have no spatial context, we extend them by coordinates. To this end, we introduce a novel intrinsic parameterization parameterization of brain volume formed by the properties of the bellace laplace-trami.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Accurate segmentation of neuroanatomy forms the basis for volume, thickness, and shape measurements from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which is extensively studied in neuroscience to track structural changes in the brain associated with aging and disease. In addition, such quantitative measurements include an enormous phenotypical characterization of an individual and can serve as endophenotypes for disease. As manual segmentation of brain MRI scans is time-consuming, computational tools have been developed to reconstruct neuroanatomy, which is particularly important for the rapidly growing number of large-scale brain studies. One of the most commonly used software tools for overall brain segmentation is FreeSurfer (Fischl et al), which applies an atlas-based segmentation strategy. This secondary work promotes research into atlas-based segments, with a focus on multiatlas techniques and brand strategies (Ashburston).

sections.heading: 2.1. Hierarchical Segmentation
sections.text: Figure 1 illustrates the hierarchical approach to overall brain segmentation in DeepNAT. In the first cascade, brain regions are divided into foreground and background. In the foreground, 25 large brain structures are shown in Figure 7. Background is the region within the brain mask that is not part of the foreground. Data that is classified as foreground passes through the next cascaded step to identify separate brain structures. Given the inherent class imbalance, hierarchical segmentation has the potential to perform better than a single-step classification that is classified in both brain regions and background. Problems with a large background class were previously known in atlas-based segmentation (Wachinger and Golland, 2014). Background is typically represented by a large data pool, while small brain structures are prone to be underrepresented.

sections.heading: 2.5. Fully Connected Conditional Random Field
sections.text: The DCNN prediction results in a probable brain segmentation. To obtain the final segmentation, we use maximum a posteriori inference to a conditional random field (CRF). CRF allows the formulation of potentials that ensure a match between narrow voxels with smooth terms and follow the image content with appearance. Traditionally, short-term CRFs are used with connections between adjacent locations (Wang et al., 2013a), which can, however, lead to an excessive smoothing of organ boundaries. In contrast, the fully connected CRF defines paired potentials on all pairs of image locations. The enormous number of paired potentials that can be defined makes conventional conclusions impractical. sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: The most important contributions were (i) multi-task learning, (ii) hierarchical segmentation, (iii) spectral coordinates and (iv) a fully networked contingent random 3D field. Multi-task learning simultaneously learns to predict labels in a small neighborhood. Spectral coordinates form an intrinsic parameterization of brain volume and provide context information on patches. The hierarchical approach takes into account the class imbalance between the background class and separate brain structures. Finally, the contingent random field ensures label alignment between narrow voxels. We train the 3D network by integrating the latest advances in deep learning to initialize weights to correct internal covariable shifts and limit the overfitting of such complex models. Our results showed the high potential of convolutionary neural networks for segmentation neuroanatomy.All epical networks are suitable for lake depth training, which is likely to be useful for deep-seeding tasks.

metadata.abstractText: We introduce DeepNAT, a 3D Deep convolutional neural network for the automatic segmentation of NeuroAnaTomy in T1-weighted magnetic resonance images. DeepNAT is an end-to-end learning-based approach to brain segmentation that jointly learns an abstract feature representation and a multi-class classification. We propose a 3D patch-based approach, where we do not only predict the center voxel of the patch but also neighbors, which is formulated as multi-task learning. To address a class imbalance problem, we arrange two networks hierarchically, where the first one separates foreground from background, and the second one identifies 25 brain structures on the foreground. Since patches lack spatial context, we augment them with coordinates. To this end, we introduce a novel intrinsic parameterization of the brain volume, formed by eigenfunctions of the Laplace-Beltrami operator. As network architecture, we use three convolutional layers with pooling, batch normalization, and non-linearities, followed by fully connected layers with dropout. The final segmentation is inferred from the probabilistic output of the network with a 3D fully connected conditional random field, which ensures label agreement between close voxels. The roughly 2.7 million parameters in the network are learned with stochastic gradient descent. Our results show that DeepNAT compares favorably to state-of-the-art methods. Finally, the purely learning-based method may have a high potential for the adaptation to young, old, or diseased brains by fine-tuning the pre-trained network with a small training sample on the target application, where the availability of larger datasets with manual annotations may boost the overall segmentation accuracy in the future.
